author: wired blogs
text: date: thu, 11 nov 1999 13:37:18 -0800 (pst) from: brian engleheart (bteheart@yahoo.com)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: dvd hack, what next?it is wrong of wired news to suggest that consumers be forced to wait for dvd-ram, or that joe salesman should nolonger be able to watch movies on his laptop while stuck in o'hare to protect studio profits ("blame us regs for dvd hack," 11.nov.99). your logic of "you can't stop the pros so stop the average joe's" is the kind of wrongheaded thinking that fostered all this copy protection foolishness to begin with.this incident illustrates that while 99 percent of the population has neither the inclination nor the time to make and distribute illegal copyrighted material, determined hackers will always find a way....the mpaa, xing, and the government all messed up and now they are going to have to live with it. regardless of what is done now there are already millions of dvd movies and players out there that the decss hack can be used on to make pirated copies.record industry executives have been screaming about losses from fraud since the cassette tape was invented while continuing to post record profits. microsoft seems to be doing ok despite the fact that one copy of windows can be installed on an infinite number of machines. dvd's acceptance has already been much delayed by the copy protection debate. for a technology publication such as wired news to coddle the irrational fears of industry weasels is shameful.
